article.title: Resonance spectra for quantum maps of kicked scattering systems by complex scaling

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following methods successfully separates the resonance spectrum from the continuous spectrum for a kicked scattering system with chaotic dynamics (κ = 11, heff = 1/50)?
In Figure 1(a), the continuous spectrum of the kicked scattering system localizes along which shape after applying complex scaling?
Figure 1(c) and 1(d) show that strong absorbing potentials and projective openings fail to produce the desired separation because:
choices: They affect the trapped set carrying semiclassical information.
They lead to a blow-up of the continuous spectrum.
They cannot be applied to chaotic systems.
They introduce unwanted periodic boundary conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2, what does the gray shaded area labeled \'S\' represent?
What is the role of the stable (Ws) and unstable (Wu) manifolds in Figure 2?
choices: They determine the positions of stable fixed points.
They define the boundaries of the scattering region.
They illustrate the trajectories of individual particles.
They represent energy levels of the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (31) states that λǫ = exp (-iǫ/ ħ). What does λǫ represent in this formula?
choices: An eigenvalue of the quantum map

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (45) describes the localization of the continuous spectrum after complex scaling as  λ(b) = exp (-ib exp (-i2θ)). What does the parameter θ represent in this formula?
Figure 9 depicts the numerically computed spectrum of the complex-scaled time-evolution operator.  What does the θ-dependent spiral structure represent?
Formula (54) defines the absorption-augmented time-evolution operator |Uη|. What is the role of the term Pη(q)?
choices: It represents the unitary time-evolution operator.
It defines the complex absorbing potential.
It projects the system onto a finite region.
It acts as an absorption operator.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 11 shows that using projective openings to compute the resonance spectrum leads to:
choices: A well-defined separation between the resonance and continuous spectra.
A loss of separation between the resonance and continuous spectra.
A spectrum identical to the one obtained with complex scaling.
A spectrum that is insensitive to the position of the opening.
